trans-unit.source: ms.ContentId: d0a07897-5fd2-41a5-856d-dc8b499c6783 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with PowerShell
trans-unit.target: ms.ContentId: d0a07897-5fd2-41a5-856d-dc8b499c6783 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing Windows Server Containers with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing Windows Server Containers with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Have questions?
trans-unit.target: Have questions?

trans-unit.source: Ask them on the <linkText>Windows Containers forum</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Ask them on the <linkText>Windows Containers forum</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Note: Windows Server Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.
trans-unit.target: Note: Windows Server Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.

trans-unit.source: To create containers with Docker instead, see <linkText>Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create containers with Docker instead, see <linkText>Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> If you want to know more, <linkText>read the FAQ</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> If you want to know more, <linkText>read the FAQ</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.
trans-unit.target: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Containers Feature.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Containers Feature.

trans-unit.source: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.
trans-unit.target: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.

trans-unit.source: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.
trans-unit.target: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.

trans-unit.source: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides: <linkText>Container Setup in Azure</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Container Setup in Hyper-V</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides: <linkText>Container Setup in Azure</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Container Setup in Hyper-V</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Basic Container Management with PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Basic Container Management with PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Start a PowerShell session by typing powershell.
trans-unit.target: Start a PowerShell session by typing powershell.

trans-unit.source: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from C:\directory> to PS C:\directory>.
trans-unit.target: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from C:\directory> to PS C:\directory>.

trans-unit.source: Use Get-Command to see the available commands in the containers module
trans-unit.target: Use Get-Command to see the available commands in the containers module

trans-unit.source: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using ipconfig and take note of this address for later use.
trans-unit.target: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using ipconfig and take note of this address for later use.

trans-unit.source: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using ipconfig you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using ipconfig you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create a New Container
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create a New Container

trans-unit.source: Before creating a Windows Server Container you will need the name of a Container Image and the name of a virtual switch that will be attached to the new container.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a Windows Server Container you will need the name of a Container Image and the name of a virtual switch that will be attached to the new container.

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-ContainerImage command to return a list of container images loaded on the host.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-ContainerImage command to return a list of container images loaded on the host.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the image name that you will use to create the container.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the image name that you will use to create the container.

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-VMSwitch command to return a list of switches available on the host.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-VMSwitch command to return a list of switches available on the host.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the switch name that will be used with the container.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the switch name that will be used with the container.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create a container.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create a container.

trans-unit.source: When running New-Container you will name the container, specify the container image, and select the network switch to use with the container.
trans-unit.target: When running New-Container you will name the container, specify the container image, and select the network switch to use with the container.

trans-unit.source: Notice in this example that the output is placed in a variable $container.
trans-unit.target: Notice in this example that the output is placed in a variable $container.

trans-unit.source: This will be helpful later in this exercise.
trans-unit.target: This will be helpful later in this exercise.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of containers on the host and verify that the container was created, use the Get-Container command.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of containers on the host and verify that the container was created, use the Get-Container command.

trans-unit.source: Notice that a container has been created with the name of MyContainer, however it has not been started.
trans-unit.target: Notice that a container has been created with the name of MyContainer, however it has not been started.

trans-unit.source: To start the container, use Start-Container proivding the name of the container.
trans-unit.target: To start the container, use Start-Container proivding the name of the container.

trans-unit.source: You can interact with containers using PowerShell remoting commands such as Invoke-Command, or Enter-PSSession.
trans-unit.target: You can interact with containers using PowerShell remoting commands such as Invoke-Command, or Enter-PSSession.

trans-unit.source: The example below creates a remote PowerShell session into the container using the Enter-PSSession command.
trans-unit.target: The example below creates a remote PowerShell session into the container using the Enter-PSSession command.

trans-unit.source: This command needs the container id in order to create the remote session.
trans-unit.target: This command needs the container id in order to create the remote session.

trans-unit.source: The container id was stored in the $container variable when the container was created.
trans-unit.target: The container id was stored in the $container variable when the container was created.

trans-unit.source: Notice that once the remote session has been created the command prompt will change to include the first 11 characters of the container id [2446380e-629].
trans-unit.target: Notice that once the remote session has been created the command prompt will change to include the first 11 characters of the container id [2446380e-629].

trans-unit.source: A container can be managed very much like a physical or virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A container can be managed very much like a physical or virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Command such as ipconfig to return the IP address of the container, mkdir to create a directory in the container and PowerShell commands like Get-ChildItem all work.
trans-unit.target: Command such as ipconfig to return the IP address of the container, mkdir to create a directory in the container and PowerShell commands like Get-ChildItem all work.

trans-unit.source: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.
trans-unit.target: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.

trans-unit.source: You can read the contents of the file to ensure the command completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: You can read the contents of the file to ensure the command completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the IP address contained in the text file matches that of the container.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the IP address contained in the text file matches that of the container.

trans-unit.source: Now that the container has been modified, exit the remote PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Now that the container has been modified, exit the remote PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Stop the container by providing the container name to the Stop-Container command.
trans-unit.target: Stop the container by providing the container name to the Stop-Container command.

trans-unit.source: When this command has completed, you will be back in control of the container host.
trans-unit.target: When this command has completed, you will be back in control of the container host.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image

trans-unit.source: An image can now be made from this container.
trans-unit.target: An image can now be made from this container.

trans-unit.source: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.
trans-unit.target: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.

trans-unit.source: To create a new image named 'newimage' use the New-ContainerImage command.
trans-unit.target: To create a new image named 'newimage' use the New-ContainerImage command.

trans-unit.source: When using this command you will specify the container to capture, a name for the new image, and additional metadata as seen below.
trans-unit.target: When using this command you will specify the container to capture, a name for the new image, and additional metadata as seen below.

trans-unit.source: Use Get-ContainerImage to return a list of Container Images.
trans-unit.target: Use Get-ContainerImage to return a list of Container Images.

trans-unit.source: Notice that a new image with the name 'newimage' has been created.
trans-unit.target: Notice that a new image with the name 'newimage' has been created.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image

trans-unit.source: Now that you have created a customized container image, go ahead and deploy a new container from this image.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have created a customized container image, go ahead and deploy a new container from this image.

trans-unit.source: Create a container named 'newcontainer' from the container image named 'newimage', output the result to a variable named '$newcontainer'.
trans-unit.target: Create a container named 'newcontainer' from the container image named 'newimage', output the result to a variable named '$newcontainer'.

trans-unit.source: Start the new container.
trans-unit.target: Start the new container.

trans-unit.source: Create a remote PowerShell session with the container.
trans-unit.target: Create a remote PowerShell session with the container.

trans-unit.source: Finally notice that this new container contains the ipconfig.txt file created earlier in this exercise.
trans-unit.target: Finally notice that this new container contains the ipconfig.txt file created earlier in this exercise.

trans-unit.source: Once you are done working with this container, exit the remote PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Once you are done working with this container, exit the remote PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.
trans-unit.target: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.

trans-unit.source: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.
trans-unit.target: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.

trans-unit.source: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.
trans-unit.target: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Container Images
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Container Images

trans-unit.source: To stop all running containers run the command below.
trans-unit.target: To stop all running containers run the command below.

trans-unit.source: If any containers are in a stopped state when you run this command, you receive a warning, which is ok.
trans-unit.target: If any containers are in a stopped state when you run this command, you receive a warning, which is ok.

trans-unit.source: Run the following to remove all containers.
trans-unit.target: Run the following to remove all containers.

trans-unit.source: To remove the container image named 'newimage', run the following.
trans-unit.target: To remove the container image named 'newimage', run the following.

trans-unit.source: Host a Web Server in a Container
trans-unit.target: Host a Web Server in a Container

trans-unit.source: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.
trans-unit.target: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.

trans-unit.source: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 – Create Container from the Windows Server Core OS Image
trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Create Container from the Windows Server Core OS Image

trans-unit.source: To create a web server container image, you first need to deploy and start a container from the Windows Server Core OS image.
trans-unit.target: To create a web server container image, you first need to deploy and start a container from the Windows Server Core OS image.

trans-unit.source: Start the container.
trans-unit.target: Start the container.

trans-unit.source: When the container is up, create a remote PowerShell session with the container.
trans-unit.target: When the container is up, create a remote PowerShell session with the container.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Install Web Server Software
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Install Web Server Software

trans-unit.source: The next step is to install the web server software.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to install the web server software.

trans-unit.source: This example will use nginx for Windows.
trans-unit.target: This example will use nginx for Windows.

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands to automatically download and extract the nginx software to c:\nginx-1.9.3.
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands to automatically download and extract the nginx software to c:\nginx-1.9.3.

trans-unit.source: Note that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.
trans-unit.target: Note that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.

trans-unit.source: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.
trans-unit.target: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.

trans-unit.source: Download the nginx software.
trans-unit.target: Download the nginx software.

trans-unit.source: Extract the nginx software.
trans-unit.target: Extract the nginx software.

trans-unit.source: This is all that needs to be completed for the nginx software installation.
trans-unit.target: This is all that needs to be completed for the nginx software installation.

trans-unit.source: Exit the remote PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Exit the remote PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Stop the container using the following command.
trans-unit.target: Stop the container using the following command.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Create Image from Web Server Container
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Create Image from Web Server Container

trans-unit.source: With the container modified to include the nginx web server software, you can now create an image from this container.
trans-unit.target: With the container modified to include the nginx web server software, you can now create an image from this container.

trans-unit.source: To do so, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To do so, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: When completed, use the Get-ContainerImage command to validate that the image has been created.
trans-unit.target: When completed, use the Get-ContainerImage command to validate that the image has been created.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginxwindows' image, use the New-Container PowerShell command.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginxwindows' image, use the New-Container PowerShell command.

trans-unit.source: Start the container.
trans-unit.target: Start the container.

trans-unit.source: Create a remote PowerShell session with the new container.
trans-unit.target: Create a remote PowerShell session with the new container.

trans-unit.source: Once working inside the container, the nginx web server can be started and web content staged.
trans-unit.target: Once working inside the container, the nginx web server can be started and web content staged.

trans-unit.source: To start the nginx web server, change to the nginx installation directory.
trans-unit.target: To start the nginx web server, change to the nginx installation directory.

trans-unit.source: Start the nginx web server.
trans-unit.target: Start the nginx web server.

trans-unit.source: And exit this PS-Session.
trans-unit.target: And exit this PS-Session.

trans-unit.source: The web server will keep running.
trans-unit.target: The web server will keep running.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 - Configure Container Networking
trans-unit.target: Step 5 - Configure Container Networking

trans-unit.source: Depending on the configuration of the container host and network, a container will either receive an IP address from a DHCP server or the container host itself using network address translation (NAT).
trans-unit.target: Depending on the configuration of the container host and network, a container will either receive an IP address from a DHCP server or the container host itself using network address translation (NAT).

trans-unit.source: This guided walk through is configured to use NAT.
trans-unit.target: This guided walk through is configured to use NAT.

trans-unit.source: In this configuration a port from the container is mapped to a port on the container host.
trans-unit.target: In this configuration a port from the container is mapped to a port on the container host.

trans-unit.source: The application hosted in the container is then accessed through the IP address / name of the container host.
trans-unit.target: The application hosted in the container is then accessed through the IP address / name of the container host.

trans-unit.source: For example if port 80 from the container was mapped to port 55534 on the container host, a typical http request to the application would look like this http://contianerhost:55534.
trans-unit.target: For example if port 80 from the container was mapped to port 55534 on the container host, a typical http request to the application would look like this http://contianerhost:55534.

trans-unit.source: This allows a container host to run many containers and allow for the applications in these containers to respond to requests using the same port.
trans-unit.target: This allows a container host to run many containers and allow for the applications in these containers to respond to requests using the same port.

trans-unit.source: For this lab we need to create this port mapping.
trans-unit.target: For this lab we need to create this port mapping.

trans-unit.source: In order to do so we will need to know the IP address of the container and the internal (application) and external (container host) ports that will be configured.
trans-unit.target: In order to do so we will need to know the IP address of the container and the internal (application) and external (container host) ports that will be configured.

trans-unit.source: For this example let’s keep it simple and map port 80 from the container to port 80 of the host.
trans-unit.target: For this example let’s keep it simple and map port 80 from the container to port 80 of the host.

trans-unit.source: Using the Add-NetNatStaticMapping command, the –InternalIPAddress will be the IP address of the container which for this walkthrough should be ‘172.16.0.2’.
trans-unit.target: Using the Add-NetNatStaticMapping command, the –InternalIPAddress will be the IP address of the container which for this walkthrough should be ‘172.16.0.2’.

trans-unit.source: When the port mapping has been created you will also need to configure an inbound firewall rule for the configured port.
trans-unit.target: When the port mapping has been created you will also need to configure an inbound firewall rule for the configured port.

trans-unit.source: To do so for port 80 run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To do so for port 80 run the following command.

trans-unit.source: This script can be copied into the VM.
trans-unit.target: This script can be copied into the VM.

trans-unit.source: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.
trans-unit.target: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article: <linkText>Set up Azure VM Endpoints</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article: <linkText>Set up Azure VM Endpoints</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Step 6 – Access the Container Hosted Website
trans-unit.target: Step 6 – Access the Container Hosted Website

trans-unit.source: With the web server container created, you can now checkout the application hosted in the container.
trans-unit.target: With the web server container created, you can now checkout the application hosted in the container.

trans-unit.source: To do so, open up a browser on different machine and enter http://containerhost-ipaddress.
trans-unit.target: To do so, open up a browser on different machine and enter http://containerhost-ipaddress.

trans-unit.source: Notice here that you will be browsing to the IP Address of the Container Host and not the container itself.
trans-unit.target: Notice here that you will be browsing to the IP Address of the Container Host and not the container itself.

trans-unit.source: If you are working from an Azure Virtual Machine this will be the public IP address or Cloud Service name.
trans-unit.target: If you are working from an Azure Virtual Machine this will be the public IP address or Cloud Service name.

trans-unit.source: If everything has been correctly configured, you will see the nginx welcome page.
trans-unit.target: If everything has been correctly configured, you will see the nginx welcome page.

trans-unit.source: At this point, feel free to update the website.
trans-unit.target: At this point, feel free to update the website.

trans-unit.source: Copy in your own sample website, or use a simple ‘Hello World’ sample site that has been created for this demo.
trans-unit.target: Copy in your own sample website, or use a simple ‘Hello World’ sample site that has been created for this demo.

trans-unit.source: To use the sample you will first need to re-establish a remote PS session with the container.
trans-unit.target: To use the sample you will first need to re-establish a remote PS session with the container.

trans-unit.source: You will first need to re-create the remote PS session with the container.
trans-unit.target: You will first need to re-create the remote PS session with the container.

trans-unit.source: Then run the following command to download and replace the index.html file.
trans-unit.target: Then run the following command to download and replace the index.html file.

trans-unit.source: After the website has been updated, navigate back to http://containerhost-ipaddress.
trans-unit.target: After the website has been updated, navigate back to http://containerhost-ipaddress.

trans-unit.source: Video Walkthrough
trans-unit.target: Video Walkthrough

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you have containers set up and an introduction to the tools, go build your own containerized apps.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have containers set up and an introduction to the tools, go build your own containerized apps.

trans-unit.source: Here is a more complete <linkText>PowerShell reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Here is a more complete <linkText>PowerShell reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Remember, this is a preview there are bugs and we have a lot of work in progress.
trans-unit.target: Remember, this is a preview there are bugs and we have a lot of work in progress.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>This page</linkText><title></title> contains many of our known issues.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>This page</linkText><title></title> contains many of our known issues.

trans-unit.source: We are also monitoring the <linkText>forums</linkText><title></title> very closely.
trans-unit.target: We are also monitoring the <linkText>forums</linkText><title></title> very closely.

trans-unit.source: There are also pre-made samples on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: There are also pre-made samples on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
